• wuž is an anaphor with antecedents in the same clause, the same sentence, or even within the discourse
  • different forms of wuž according to nominal class and case: wuž, žu, že, již
  • wuže: wuž (wuž-ERG wuž-ABS): 'double reflexive'; the first wuž takes the case of the agent, the second one of the patient; the choice between the light and the heavy reflexive depends on "whether a target of reflexivization is a core or an oblique argument of the verb" and "whether a situation described is inwardly or outwardly oriented" (Lyutikova 2000: 242)
  • wuž alone may be long-distance bound
repr:
• in our graphemic representations we follow the source (Lyutikova 2000), where no phonetic realizations of the relevant symbols are indicated
  • "z wedge" ‹ž› used here to represent the "yogh wedge" that is used in the reference cited; its phonetic realization is a voiced post-alveolar affricate
  • for the "yogh" sign see Pullum, G./W. Ladusaw (1986). Phonetic Symbol Guide. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.

comments:
• intensifier is usually used in cleft constructions with a nominalized relative clause and possessive marking (cf. ex. 370)
  • the intensifier alaʔa probably exhibits the same semantics as Breton end-eeun, Mixtec máá- and Zapotec la-gahk
  • orungu-POSS: orungu- means 'body'

pronouns (PRO): tan- (referentially defective anaphor; requires local antecedent)
-kon: verbal reflexive or middle voice

light reflexives: he: (ACC), hôu (GEN), hô:i (DAT); heavy reflexives (third person): he:autón (ACC), he:autoû (GEN), heautô: (DAT); paradigm of intensifiers (MASC): autós, autoû, autô:; the simple reflexive he: is confined to referring back to antecedents from higher clauses (can be used only logophorically); in a local context, the complex reflexive he:auto- has to be used; the intensifier may either follow or precede the NP it combines with
misimu may be used to reinforce the verbal reflexivization strategy (cf. ex. 529)

-ka: past form of middle
-kan: non-past form of middle
adverbial intensifier -aʔkstu reinforces verbal reflexive and is in some contexts obligatory
repr:
<q>: uvular stop
<lh>: voiceless alveolar lateral
<x>: voiceless postalveolar fricative
<ch>: voiceless alveolar affricate

lex: laa: pronominal stem, regularly shortened to la if not accented; gahk: 'exactly, right'
comments: the adjunct reflexive lagahk is optional; a simple pronoun can also be locally bound

PRO ta: 'that which belongs to PRO' (mine, yours etc.)
special reflexive only in the third person
the third person reflexive is phonologically identical to the pronoun of the second person

adn construction: NP/(PRO) P hoore POSS.PRO; the intensifier is linked to the head NP by some preposition: in some dialects this preposition is gam ('because of'; cf. the paradigm below), and in others bee ('with')
there is also a verbal middle voice with paradigms varying according to tense and mood distinctions
tigi: also means 'exactly'
alternative own: POSS.PRO halal

sort:
probably ADN not with inanimates
AVE is possible with inanimates ('by itself'; cf. example 724)
comments:
<r>: alveolar flap; <rr>: alveolar trill
LNK (bound linker): -n-; expresses adnominal relationship
IND.LNK (independent linker): na/ta
paradigm of intensifiers:
dà: 'with'
own: also NP-LNK IND.LNK kâi-LNK-POSS (emphatic, 'very own')
scalar focus particle koo: often with negative polarity

-mí-: verbal reflexive, fully productive
both intensifiers (mɔ́kɔ́ and mpenjá) are basically equivalent; according to Guthrie (1966), mpenjá is preferred in combination with reflexives and mɔ́kɔ́ elsewhere (Guthrie 1966: 50)
scalar focus particle: also atâ

otherint: moyo wangu ('soul my'), nafsi yangu ('soul my'); cf. Arabic nafs-
comments:
ji-: verbal reflexivization strategy
NC: nominal class marker
paradigm of -enyewe for NC1 (mainly human):
1SG: (mimi) mw-enyewe
2SG: (wewe) mw-enyewe
3SG: (yeye) mw-enyewe
1PL: (sisi) w-enyewe
2PL: (ninyi) w-enyewe
3PL: (wao) w-enyewe

otherint: free pronoun plus corresponding (non-reflexive) pronominal clitic
comments: -tju/-nku (cf. the paradigms below) adjoin to NPs/pronouns.

lex: dodoc might be a reduplicated form of the reciprocal marker d-oco-b (3SG.OBJ-DIFF.SBJ-3SG.SUBJ) (J. Roberts, p.c.)
comments:
dodoc only attaches to personal pronouns;
DIFF.SBJ: different subject (switch-reference system)

otherint: da: 'exactly' (emphatic particle stressing the precise referential or spatiotemporal correctness of the preceding constituent, Heath 1999: 265)
paradigms:
subject personal pronouns (cf. Heath 1999b: 79):
1SG: ay
2SG: n, ni
3SG: a(non-reflexive)
3SG: ŋga(reflexive and logophoric)
1PL: it
2PL: war
3PL: i(non-reflexive)
3PL: ŋgey / ŋgii
comments:
in a local context (coreferential co-arguments), the compound reflexive is regularly used (ŋga boŋ); the light reflexive ŋga is chiefly used in long-distance bound contexts (coreference of clause- or sentence mates that are not co-arguments
both the intensifier and the reflexive derive from body-part nouns, but from different ones (hundey< hundi 'breath, soul, life'; boŋ: 'head')
nda: 'with'
AVE is expressed as 'with + heavy reflexive'/'with x's head'
hinne, hinna also means 'alone, only, immediately'
alternative adv. exclusive intensifier: hinne, hinna

there seems to be no semantic (near-)equivalent to intensifier constructions in Chamorro
reflexivity can also be signalled by simple pronouns, i.e. na maisa optionally precedes or follows the pronoun in reflexive-marking
maisa also means 'alone'
na is a linker used in attributive constructions

country: Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia (Asia), Tajikistan, Turkey (Asia), Turkmenistan, Ukraine
comments: tav-: 'head'; -it: instrumental;

country: Russell Islands, northwest of Guadalcanal, central Solomons
comments: reflexive constructions with POSS-muan are often avoided, and reflexivity is indicated by means of an intransivtiising suffix (-a).

sarili: also 'individual'
the etymology of sarili is unclear
sa is a preposition, ari means 'property'
is immi- etymologically related to (contained in) nammineq?

country: Dagestan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkey (Asia), Turkmenistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan
comments:
the suffix -ni is additive and has both a non-scalar ('also, too') and a scalar reading ('even')
the scalar reading can be made more explicit by adding the particle kwaz, which is originally a converb of the verb kwa 'be under/among' (cf. Haspelmath 1993: 237)
Reflexive amji is invariant

the position of PRON/ANPH-tɨ́rɔ̀ seems to be considerably parallel to English, insofar as AVE is sentence-final and ADN is adjacent to its head NP (cf. Kutsch Lojenga 1994: 200)
the reflexive ndɨ̀- is used only in the third person; in the first and second person the regular object pronouns are used (cf. German and other European languages that do not have specialized reflexive forms in the first and second person)
lexical source of reflexive ndɨ̀-: 'skin'

paradigms:
paradigm of 'PRO seefi ':
1SG: mi seefi
2SG: i seefi
3SG: en seefi
1PL: wi seefi
2PL: u seefi
3PL: den seefi
comments:
PRO: in the third person, the oblique pronoun (en, vs. the subject pronoun a) is used; in the first and second person there is no case distinction
seefi is obligatory in combination with a preceding unbound pronominal
seefi is invariant (cf. the paradigm below)
seefi is also used in a number of other functions, e.g. as an adjective of token identity ('the same', cf. ex. 780) and as an intensifying negative polarity item ('at all', 'whatsoever'; cf. ex. 654)
alternative lexical item meaning 'own': (PRO/NP) éigi (according to Huttar & Huttar 1994: 471, eigi is preferred over seefi by younger speakers)

falapetsi is an intransitive verb and literally means 'do alone/by oneself, do (an action) without participants other than the agent(s)'
it can be used in conjunction with argument suppression to indicate reflexivity (see above).

with typically self-directed verbs, the simple pronouns are used in reflexive contexts; self is gaining ground, and is becoming more obligatory with verbs denoting typically other-directed activities, acccording to Donaldson (1993: Section 8.20): "The reflexivity of verbs and their use with or without the compound pronoun in -self is something that is in a state of flux in Afrikaans." Among other things, this concerns "the use of the compound form in -self whre historically it was not required or was even considered incorrect" (Donaldson 1993: 291)

paradigms:
PRO + INT:
SG
NOM: ik/gij/hij zelf
GEN: mijns/uws/zijns zelf-s
DAT: mij/u/hem zelv-en
ACC: mij/u/hem zelv-en
PL
NOM: wij/gij/zij zelv-en
GEN: (van) ons/u/hen zelv-en
DAT: ons/u/hun zelv-en
ACC: ons/u/hen zelv-en
comments: zelv- inflects for case (weak adjectival inflection); however, Verbeek (1917: 90) mentions that "some writers use zelf as an invariant form, like German selbst"
